Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Training Next Generation Faculty and Students to Address the Infrastructure Crisis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This TUES Type 2 project is establishing the Center for Infrastructure Transformation and Education (CIT-E) as the centerpiece of a community of practice. The aim is to facilitate the transformation of undergraduate civil and environmental engineering programs by incorporating infrastructure topics into their existing curriculum. This project builds upon the sophomore-level courses and other modules on civil infrastructure developed by the Civil and Environmental Engineering (CEE) Department of the University of Wisconsin-Platteville and the Civil Engineering program at West Point Military Academy. The six collaborating institutions are of varying sizes, student population, and settings (Arizona State University, New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, Norwich University, Portland State University, Rowan University, and University of Toledo). The project objectives are to: 1) establish and sustain the Center for Infrastructure Transformation and Education (CIT-E) as the source for infrastructure education materials that can be continuously improved by a community of practice, 2) develop educational expertise in infrastructure topics and in pedagogy in faculty at collaborating institutions, 3) deliver, assess, and institutionalize infrastructure-themed courses or modules for CEE and other majors at collaborating institutions, 4) enhance the ability of CEE students to view components and systems designed in CEE sub-disciplines as integral parts of the larger infrastructure system, and 5) enhance the ability of CEE students to view infrastructure challenges from a societal, rather than solely technical, perspective.

The project employs a creative model that engages collaborating faculty in roles of content creators and module maintainers of the infrastructure-themed course material to develop and sustain the community of practice. In addition, a structured plan to facilitate the adoption and institutionalization of infrastructure curricular material at the six collaborating institutions, and provide faculty development and support is used.

More than 500 students and fifteen faculty at eight diverse institutions, including some with large numbers of underrepresented minority students, are directly impacted by the project activities, increasing the number of students and faculty with knowledge and expertise in sustainable infrastructure topics. A community of practice centered on CIT-E and multiple faculty development workshops is employed to facilitate the dissemination and adoption of the curricular material and practices developed in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The introduction of sophomore level infrastructure courses at the University of Wisconsin-Platteville and at the United States Military Academy at West Point, along with the incorporation of infrastructure content into existing courses at these institutions, not only prepared students to plan, design, maintain, and renovate infrastructure, but also allowed them to gain a better understanding of how the different fields of civil engineering relate to one another; to view infrastructure as a system; to recognize how the quality of infrastructure affects society, the economy, and individuals’ daily lives. The success of these courses at these institutions coupled with the interest of representatives from other undergraduate civil and environmental engineering (CEE) programs in adopting similar courses lead to the development of the collaborative project entitled: Training Next Generation Faculty and Students to Address the Infrastructure Crisis.

The main objectives of this project were (1) to establish and sustain the Center for Infrastructure Transformation and Education (CIT-E) as the source for infrastructure education materials that is continuously improved by a vibrant community of practice; (2) to develop educational expertise in infrastructure topics and in pedagogy in faculty at collaborating institutions; (3) to deliver, assess, and institutionalize infrastructure-themed courses or modules for CEE majors and other majors at collaborating institutions; (4) to enhance the ability of CEE students to view components and systems designed in CEE subdisciplines as integral parts of a larger system (i.e. the infrastructure); and (5) to enhance the ability of CEE students to view infrastructure challenges from a societal perspective, rather than solely from a technical perspective.

The CIT-E was successfully established in 2013 and to date, the database of participants includes 125 people who are either actively involved, have expressed interest in being involved in the future, or have attended one of the CIT-E workshops. Community engagement steadily increased over the years, as collaborators from several universities became interested in adopting infrastructure courses at their home institutions and sharing materials created for their courses. A total of sixteen universities adapted CIT-E materials to teach an infrastructure-related course at their institution. Other universities have already expressed interest in starting similar courses in the near future. This community has been successfully providing support and mentorship to instructors interested in teaching infrastructure based courses. It also provides great opportunities for members to share best practices and newly-discovered resources. Once the original objectives were met, the CIT-E community decided to expand on the proposed outcomes and in addition to sharing existing course material as originally proposed, it started to create a complete model introductory infrastructure course with peer-reviewed lessons.

At the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology (New Mexico Tech), Dr. Claudia Wilson, a member of the CIT-E community and the PI for New Mexico Tech, developed an upper division course in Infrastructure which she taught in the Fall Semester of 2016 to 18 undergraduate students (juniors and seniors) in Civil Engineering and a graduate student in Petroleum Engineering. She plans to offer the course again in the Fall Semester of 2018. She also contributed to the development of the model introductory infrastructure course being developed collaboratively by members of the CIT-E community by assisting in the development of learning outcomes for lessons in the Transportation Module of the course, creating a complete lesson for this Module, including pre-, in-, and post-class activities, instructor resources and guidelines, and reviewing lessons developed by her peers.

The CIT-E community strongly believes that a more effectively trained and educate engineering workforce in the area of infrastructure will be better equipped to plan, design, operate, and maintain a sustainable infrastructure.
